text: [Music]
um hi everyone Classics week is over now
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a classic review of
The Avalanches album since I left you
this is the legendary and groundbreaking
debut album from the ever evolving
Australian music outfit known as The
Avalanches originally completed in the
year 2000 the creation and eventual
viral spread of since I left you was a
long and winding process which involved
lineup changes sample clearances and
slowly growing critical Acclaim the
avalanche's musical journey and
evolution is far from over but for a
while it seemed like it was as since I
left you remain to be the group's only
album until the eventual follow-up
Wildflower 16 years later which was then
proceeded by we will always love you in
2020 and while the group hasn't
completely abandoned their plunderphonic
Roots it is clear in recent years they
have been focusing more on psychedelic
pop Aesthetics original material guest
features and clearly have no desire to
just recreate what they did on this
record I mean I don't even think they
could if they wanted to as it was such a
long time ago one of the key founders of
the group has since left not to mention
the financial risks and legal holdups
involved in dropping a record that has
hundreds if not thousands of samples
laced into it so the Avalanches are a
pretty different band at this point but
at the time of this record's creation
they consisted of founding members
Robbie chatter Darren seltman Tony De
blasi and Gordon the quilton and
additionally Dexter fabay and James De
La Cruz the Avalanche is also built up
to the release of this album with their
1997 El producto EP which had its fair
share of samples on it but was mostly an
experimental hip-hop release that had a
lot of Beastie Boys influence on it in
contrast since I left you as more of an
instrumental experience so long as you
count its various vocal chops as a
larger Sonic tapestry being woven here
as it's pretty clear all the source
material here is being manipulated and
flipped around to create some something
wholly unique and a wildly different
experience which is what makes sense I
left you so amazing because in the years
since its release this thing remains to
be the gold standard for sample based
dance music as the tracks on this record
hit a level of detail and Nuance
Dynamics and style that most stuff in
this Lane just doesn't have even prior
Classics such as DJ Shadows introducing
which I have also reviewed and even a
lot of newer records that have the
advantage of being made with more
advanced technology than what was
available in 1999. it took years but
since I left you brought modern music to
the fullest and most Artful realization
of what early hip-hop producers like
steinsky were doing in the early 80s
because the tracks on this thing aren't
just groovy and fun there's a
kaleidoscopic Majesty to them that is
pretty striking right from the opening
track with its refined string samples
Woodwinds and Youthful vocal chops the
way all these sounds bleed together over
these distant disco rhythms I don't know
if I'm listening to is from a dance
floor or a Dream from here we have a
seamless transition into the following
stay another season if you listen to
this LP you will find there is kind of a
continuous flow moving from track to
track to track so there is like a
holistic momentum to the entire record
which most definitely adds to the magic
I also love how the groove changes on
this track into something ritzier and
more Funk based but still quite a few
familiar instrumental elements from the
previous track remain and take on a
slightly different shape there's a
gradual progression to this track too
and many of these you know little shifts
and nuances in Groove and detail over
the course of this album are
consistently impressive the way certain
samples are applied on this record too
for example there's this uh one
squealing tone that sticks out pretty
boldly in the mix one that doesn't sound
too much unlike what production Crews
such as Public Enemies the bomb squad
would do back in the day grabbing like a
wild chunk of saxophone just screaming
out and throwing that into an already
cluttered mix The Avalanches are
scratching a very similar itch here but
the sound they're using in this case
sound sounds like a horse very
aggressively neighing but unless you're
really listening to it and thinking of
it in that way it might just fly by you
as just another piece of instrumentation
the plunder phonic magic of this album
continues onto the song radio who's very
fuzzy and static laced grooves sound
like competing am frequencies creating a
very great but very unlikely Dance Mix
then the zany collage intro on the
following two hearts and three four time
eventually settles into one of the most
relaxing and beautiful grooves on the
entire record and obviously it's in 342
which is something that you don't often
hear in a lot of plunder phonic and
Hip-Hop based You Know instrumental
music but between all the swirling
electronic keyboards and CRP effects
it's pretty clear that the Avalanches
are going for something here that's a
much more trippy and sweet just for
contrast the following Avalanche rock
interlude has one of the chunkiest rap
beats on the entire record plus a pretty
prominent rayquan vocal sample which
flows flawlessly into the ever tense
Electro grooves that sound like a huge
throwback back on the next track flight
tonight which evolves across its four
minute run time with such grandiosity it
feels like I am experiencing some kind
of mind-expanding acid trip meanwhile
close to you has so many varied passages
within it it feels like four songs
within one with a lot of hypnotic and
gentle fiddle licks as well as these
really hard-hitting group choruses that
selling something straight out of a
roller disco in fact I kind of wonder
how this record would play over the
sound system from front to back at a
roller disco especially given how hard
the cyclical grooves hit on the track
different feeling which feels like a
more pillowy and sweet version of
something you would hear from Daft
Punk's homework era which it's crazy to
think this thing dropped around the same
time as their album Discovery because
given the quality of artistry and detail
that Avalanche has laced into this
project it feels like something that
could have easily been dropped five or
six years after the fact the song toward
the end of the record live at Domino's
sounds pretty Daft Punk inspired as well
the track list from here continue used
to sound like the most amazing surreal
and exciting DJ set ever the operatic
intro vocals on electricity flow
whimsically into more disco rhythms
underscored by some amazing slap bass
licks as well as robotic sound effects
then the track tonight is a gorgeous and
Serene little piano section that guides
the record into a somewhat ambient
passage just before we hit one of the
biggest Bops on the entire LP Frontier
psychiatrist with its huge horn hits
heavy beat and epic DJ scratches this is
handily one of the funniest and most
colorful moments on the entire LP that
boy needs therapy I'm gonna kill you
rarely is something so impressively epic
but also just downright silly at the
same time then ito's combination of
Woodwinds acoustic guitars driving
grooves as well as robotic vocal hits
make for a mix of elements that are
rigid but then also fluid that's kind of
unique while the beautiful summer Crane
and little journey continue to expand
the more ambient spacious and
experimental side of the record the
closing track extra Kings I see as a
perfect finish to this album and
definitely shows that the band I was
looking at this project very
holistically because this one feels like
the soundtrack to whatever alien race
created this album saying goodbye and
soaring away on their spaceship probably
the best way I could describe this track
but yeah that is this fun groovy
danceable colorful and unique classic
ass album It's amazing And most
definitely worth your time even if
you've heard it before and uh yeah
